thread.title: Hatchery crews working overtime to save as many fish as possible due to extreme drought-like conditions
thread.title_full: Hatchery crews working overtime to save as many fish as possible due to extreme drought-like conditions | The Seattle Times

author: Mark Yuasa
title: Hatchery crews working overtime to save as many fish as possible due to extreme drought-like conditions
text:
The summer drought and heat wave are taking a toll on fish in hatcheries, and state Fish and Wildlife hatchery personnel are doing their best to save as many fish as possible.
More than 12 of the 83 fish hatcheries run by state Fish and Wildlife are suffering from low water levels or high water temperatures, which can lead to disease and mortality of fish.
Ron Warren, the state Fish and Wildlife salmon policy coordinator, said in a news release that about 1.5 million juvenile fish have been lost from drought conditions in hatcheries.
“This is unlike anything we’ve seen for some time,” he stated in the news release.
Most Read Stories Seattle company copes with backlash on $70,000 minimum wage Man shot dead in South Seattle while on phone with mom Seahawks sign four-year extension with linebacker Bobby Wagner worth a reported $43 million Impressions from Day 2 of Seahawks' training camp Higher wages a surprising success for Seattle restaurant Ivar's The Soos Creek Hatchery on the Green River near Auburn has seen a die-off of 34,000 summer steelhead (50 percent of the fish total) and 153,000 coho (18 percent) from diseases related to the warm water.
Hatchery crews are using re-circulation pumps and aerators to keep the water cooler, and in some instances the fish are being fed a medicated feed to avoid fungal and bacterial infections.
Other ways to help quell the situation include moving fish to other hatchery facilities that have cooler water. State fisheries moved about 102,000 coho from the North Toutle Hatchery to Tacoma Power’s Cowlitz Hatchery.
Some fish have been released into river and lakes along with agreement by co-managers. The Icy Creek Hatchery is releasing about 107,000 fall chinook that are around eight months old. The young fish should be able to survive an early release, and were originally supposed to be released in July of 2016.
